awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHA) bioplastics produced from waste resources
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of biodegradable plastics from waste resources to replace petroleum-based plastics in packaging.  Continually increasing demand for plastic packaging, coupled with the inevitable escape of plastic waste into the environment, is posing a monumental pollution issue for the world. Entities within the consumer goods value chain have a pressing need to address these issues, manifested in the form of changing customer demands and legislative pressures. Unfortunately, recycling is not a feasible global solution. Also, most currently available bioplastic alternatives are not considered viable due to issues of cost, sustainability, functionality, and/or biodegradability. The successful development and commercialization of novel biodegradable plastics for packaging may not only address an environmental need for sustainability, but also may create a stronger packaging economy driven by technologies that address both commercial and environmental problems.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of polyhydroxyalkanoate (PHA) copolymers produced from waste resources. Implementation of PHAs has long been hindered by lack of versatility in the material, as well as production technologies based on using food crops. Upcycling abundant waste streams into novel PHA copolymers and blends may overcome these hindrances and address the technical challenges required for PHAs to replace petroleum-based plastics in packaging. Basing production of PHAs on waste resources may significantly reduce the cost and improve the sustainability of production. Currently, commercialized PHA technologies are limited to incorporating only a handful of different PHA monomers, such as the 4-carbon polyhydroxybutyrate (PHB) and the medium chain length (MCL) 6-carbon PHA polyhydroxyhexanoate (PHHx). Important properties for industrial application of bioplastics, such as the melting temperature, crystallization kinetics, elasticity, and Young’s modulus, may be improved by incorporation of different monomer units into the biopolymer product. Research and development into this proposed technology has demonstrated feasible production of a whole family of PHB-co-MCL copolymers and blends, incorporating all monomer units from 4 to 14 carbons. This may allow for production of a diverse array of fully biodegradable bio-based packaging materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry

por.por_cntn:
I-Corps: Polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHA) bioplastics produced from waste resources is a project that was submitted to investigate the market and commercialization potential of a waste-to-bioplastic technology developed through the support of SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry, the Research Foundation of SUNY, and the Center for Sustainable Materials Management. The mission of this undertaking is to, by bringing this technology to market, solve pressing environmental issues of plastic pollution while simultaneously stimulating the American economy with new, high tech green jobs and providing the social service of improved waste management infrastructure. 

The findings and education gained throughout the program identified a strong market need in a particular segment of packaging - paper and fiber based packaging. Equipped with market and customer knowledge gained through the course, we were successful in developing partnerships and buy-in with several major members of the fiber-based packaging industry keenly interested in supporting this technology so that it may help them meet emerging opportunities in new sustainability verticals. This compelling information catalyzed the full PCT patent filing of the germane technology, as well as licensing of the technology to a start-up: Retrn Bioworks Inc. 

The I-Corps program was a success for our team in 3 disctinct ways:

1. Development and Validation of a Technology-Related Business Model Through the support of the NSF I-Corps Teams program, our team received the necessary training to intelligently conduct customer discovery interviews, synthesize data, and development a business model relevant to our technological development in waste-upcycled biodegradable bioplastics. 

2. Customer Discovery and Problem-Solution Fit Through the continued support of the program, our team was able to identify and develop relationships with key customers in the segments identified during Activity 1. These customer relationships were critical for lending credence to the business model and problem solution fit, as well as guiding further prototyping and product specification related R&D. 

3. Prototype Development Lastly, the program helped support our group to continue prototype development using our bioplastic technology, with grounding in our customer discovery interviews and guidance from customer/industry partners.

Since then, the Retrn team has garnered significant additional support and validation from many state and federal programs, including: The Center for Sustainable Materials Management, the RF SUNY Office of Industry and External Affairs, Binghamton University XCEED Program, Columbia Tech Ventures NYSERDA Entrepreneur in Residence and CxO programs, Koffman Southern Tier Incubator, Syracuse Center of Excellence, Syracuse University Blackstone Launchpad. Also, the team won the Fuzehub Commercialization Competition, was accepted into the Launch NY program, accepted into the Venture for Climate Tech Bootcamp, and was selected for the Cornell Center for Materials Research Jumpstart Program as well as the Cornell Life Science Ventures Incubator. Lastly, we have most recently been awarded a Phase I STTR to continue development and commercialization of these technologies as barrier coatings in the fiber-based food packaging markets. 

The sum of these accomplishments is a fully developed founding team, demonstration of working prototypes, and a sound business plan and partnership to move this technology from the ideation it was at the beginning of the I Corps program to a fully operational and well supported early-stage startup. 

Throughout the journey described, the learnings from the I Corps program were absolutely essential and used time and time again at every partner and customer meeting, investor pitch, and internal strategy session. In short, assistance through the I-Corps program catalyzed the development of the people and technology on this team from idea to reality. 


Last Modified: 04/05/2024
Modified by: Bandaru V Ramarao
